material.mattext:
Quiz 2 - Transformation matrices, Euler angles, and quaternions

This quiz covers Section 2.5-3.3 of the notes.

 Instructions

  • This quiz consists of 10 questions, covering content from the previous week.
  • You are allowed to submit the quiz an unlimited number of times with no time limit, and on each submission you can review each incorrect question attempt after the fact.
  • When reattempting the quiz, only the previously incorrect question(s) from the last attempted quiz will be available to attempt. The correct question(s) from the last attempted quiz will automatically be added to your score.
Match the principle axis rotation with the corresponding rotation matrix.
In general, a homogeneous transformation matrix encodes
the pose (translation and orientation) of one reference frame with respect to another.
the translation of one reference frame with respect to another.
the rotation of one reference frame with respect to another.

The transformation matrix encoding the pose of frame \(X\) with respect to frame \(Y\) is given by

$$ {^Y{\bf T}_X}=\begin{bmatrix} {^X{\bf R}_Y} & {^X{\bf t}_Y}\\  [0,0,0] &  1  \end{bmatrix}. $$

Correct! 

The transformation matrix encoding the pose of frame \(X\) with respect to frame \(Y\) is given by

$$ {^Y{\bf T}_X}=\begin{bmatrix} {^Y{\bf R}_X} & {^Y{\bf t}_X}\\  [0,0,0] &  1  \end{bmatrix}. $$
Match the following transformation matrices with the correct pose description.
A null rotation matrix and a translation vector of \( {^W{\bf t}_B}=[1,2,3]^T\)
A rotation of \(\alpha\) about \(\hat{\bf z}_W\) and a translation vector of \( {^W{\bf t}_B}=[1,2,3]^T\)
A rotation of \(\alpha\) about \(\hat{\bf y}_W\) and a translation vector of \( {^W{\bf t}_B}=[1,2,3]^T\)
A rotation of \(\alpha\) about \(\hat{\bf x}_W\) and a translation vector of \( {^W{\bf t}_B}=[1,2,3]^T\)
In the context of Euler angles, how many valid rotation orders are there, given that one cannot rotate about the same axis twice (e.g. ZYX is valid, whereas ZZX is invalid)?

Euler angles are constructed by performing three sequential rotations. In the case of intrinsic ZYX Euler angles, match the correct rotation instance with the associated rotational axis. You can assume that the respectively newly formed frames, in order, are \(\{Z\}\), \(\{Y\}\), and \(\{X\}\).

Given the rotation matrix of

$$ {^W{\bf R}_B}=\begin{bmatrix} 0.8138 &  -0.0065 & 0.5811 \\ 0.4698 & -0.5811 & -0.6645\\ 0.3420 &  0.8138 & -0.4698   \end{bmatrix}, $$

The Euler angles, in degrees, are given by
Given the quaternion, \( {^W{\bf q}_B} = [0.4367,0.8463,0.1369,0.2727]^T\), the corresponding quaternion inverse is given by
Given the quaternion, \( {^W{\bf q}_B} = [0.4367,0.8463,0.1369,0.2727]^T\), the corresponding rotation angle, \(\alpha\), and rotation vector, \(^W\hat{v}\), is given by

Given the rotation matrix

$$ {^W{\bf R}_B}=\begin{bmatrix} 0.7071 &  0 & 0.7071 \\ 0 & 1 & 0\\ -0.7071 &  0 & 0.7071   \end{bmatrix}, $$

determine the corresponding quaternion, \(^W{\bf q}_B\).
